qas.question: What is the name of Popper's model of evolution?
Popper's model of evolution is part of what family of models?
What directs the actions of organisms in Popper's biological model?
Organisms' goals shift along with which notable genetic process?
In which model do living organisms not have goals?
What is the least sophisticated form of organisms with central control?
What is a species of higher complexity than the human brain?
What are mutations in the genes not able to change?
What does Popper think is more likely to be lethal to an organism than changes of phenotype?

context: Instead, he formulated the <a0_0><b4_0>spearhead<a0_0/> model of evolution<b4_0/>, a version of <a1_0>genetic pluralism<a1_0/>. According to this model, living organisms themselves have <a2_0>goals<a2_0/>, and act according to these goals, each guided by a central control. In its most sophisticated form, this is <b5_0>the brain of humans<b5_0/>, but controls also exist in much less sophisticated ways for species of lower complexity, such as the <b6_0>amoeba<b6_0/>. This control organ plays a special role in evolution—it is the "spearhead of evolution". The goals bring the purpose into the world. <a3_0>Mutations<a3_0/> in the genes that determine the structure of the control may then cause drastic changes in <b7_0>behaviour<b7_0/>, preferences and goals, without having an impact on the organism's phenotype. Popper postulates that such purely <b8_0>behavioural changes<b8_0/> are less likely to be lethal for the organism compared to drastic changes of the phenotype.
